a. a. michelson.gloss: United States physicist (born in Germany) who collaborated with Morley in the Michelson-Morley experiment (1852-1931)

a. a. milne.gloss: English writer of stories for children (1882-1956)

aa.gloss: an international organization that provides a support group for persons trying to overcome alcoholism

aaa.gloss: an aneurysm of the abdominal aorta associated with old age and hypertension

aachen.gloss: a city in western Germany near the Dutch and Belgian borders

aaland islands.gloss: an archipelago of some 6,000 islands in the Gulf of Bothnia under Finnish control

aalborg.gloss: a city and port in northern Jutland

aalto.gloss: Finnish architect and designer of furniture (1898-1976)

aar.gloss: a river in north central Switzerland that runs northeast into the Rhine

aardvark.gloss: nocturnal burrowing mammal of the grasslands of Africa that feeds on termites

aardwolf.gloss: striped hyena of southeast Africa that feeds chiefly on insects

aare.gloss: a river in north central Switzerland that runs northeast into the Rhine

aare river.gloss: a river in north central Switzerland that runs northeast into the Rhine

aarhus.gloss: port city of Denmark in eastern Jutland

aaron.gloss: United States professional baseball player who hit more home runs than Babe Ruth (born in 1934)

aaron's rod.gloss: tall-stalked very woolly mullein with densely packed yellow flowers

aaron burr.gloss: United States politician who served as vice president under Jefferson

aaron copland.gloss: United States composer who developed a distinctly American music (1900-1990)

aaron montgomery ward.gloss: United States businessman who in 1872 established a successful mail-order business (1843-1913)

aarp.gloss: an association of people to promote the welfare of senior citizens

synonyms.word: association for the advancement of retired persons

aas.gloss: an associate degree in applied science

aave.gloss: a nonstandard form of American English characteristically spoken by African Americans in the United States

aah.gloss: express admiration and pleasure by uttering `ooh' or `aah'
